title: Daily Evening Bhagavatam Discourse | HH Stoka Krishna Swami | SB 1.7.19 | 01-01-2022
speaker: HH Stoka Krishna Swami

segments.key_quote: In this session we will be discussing from the 19th verse of the 7th chapter of the 1st canto of Srimad Bhagavatham.
segments.summary: The lecture begins with traditional Vaishnava prayers and an introduction to the topic: Srimad Bhagavatam, Canto 1, Chapter 7, Verse 19.

segments.key_quote: When the Sun son of the Brahmana Ashwathama saw that his horses were tired he considered that there was no alternative for protection outside of his using the ultimate weapon.
segments.summary: The speaker narrates the story of Ashwathama using the Brahmastra, explaining the context of Arjuna chasing him and Ashwathama's desperation.

segments.key_quote: In the ultimate issue only when there is no alternative the nuclear weapon called the Brahmastra is applied even though this Brahmastra works on the power of mantra the power of mantra is applied even though this Brahmastra works on the power of mantra even though this Brahmastra works on the power of mantra still it is like modern-day nuclear weapon
segments.summary: Srila Prabhupada explains that the Brahmastra is like a nuclear weapon, possessing immense power and radiation, despite being powered by mantra.

segments.key_quote: The most intelligent man is called a Brahmana. And it is not a hereditary title.
segments.summary: The speaker explains that being a Brahmana is not hereditary but based on qualification, and Ashwathama is referred to as the son of a Brahmana because he lacks the necessary qualities.

segments.key_quote: A Brahmana naturally is endowed with some characteristics by which he is called a Brahmana.
segments.summary: The speaker elaborates on the qualities of a Brahmana as described in the Bhagavad Gita, contrasting it with the modern misconception of Brahmanas being determined by birth.

segments.key_quote: Since Ashwathama's decision is immature, he is purposely called herein the son of a Brahmana.
segments.summary: Ashwathama's immature decision to use the Brahmastra is why he is referred to as the son of a Brahmana, highlighting his lack of qualification.

segments.key_quote: One is identified as a Brahmana or any particular varna, Kshatriya or Vaishya, based on lakshana, based on characteristics.
segments.summary: The speaker explains that the Vedic system identifies individuals based on their characteristics (lakshana) rather than birth, citing the Bhagavatam.

segments.key_quote: One must act as a Brahmana. One must have the characteristics of a Brahmana. If he does not have those characteristics, there is no harm in referring him as the son of a Brahmana.
segments.summary: The speaker emphasizes the importance of acting and having the characteristics of a Brahmana, and that referring to someone as the son of a Brahmana is acceptable if they lack these qualities, highlighting the need for training, education, and culture.

segments.key_quote: Just like somebody's father is a great heart surgeon. If the son is not qualified as a heart surgeon. How can the son be referred to as a great heart surgeon. It is not proper.
segments.summary: The speaker uses the analogy of a heart surgeon to illustrate that one cannot claim to be like their qualified father without possessing the same qualities, and explains how Draupadi advised Arjuna to spare Ashwathama's life out of compassion for his mother.

segments.key_quote: The Brahmastra could be the only way he could protect himself. Now Brahmastra is to be used in a very very very extraordinary circumstance. It is the last weapon somebody may use.
segments.summary: The speaker describes Ashwathama's use of the Brahmastra and its effects, comparing it to a nuclear weapon, and explains how Krishna advised Arjuna to counteract it, contrasting it with the lack of counteraction for modern nuclear weapons.

segments.key_quote: Formerly they had this knowledge. If I throw one kind of weapon. Somebody else may neutralize that weapon by throwing another weapon.
segments.summary: The speaker discusses the regulated warfare of Kshatriyas, including the use of different weapons and their counteraction, contrasting it with the lack of principles and regulations in modern warfare, and concludes the lecture with gratitude and Hare Krishna.
